Quantum Bayesian Networks

Project - Quantum Computing

Implementation of Bayesian networks as quantum circuits for probabilistic modeling. By exploiting amplitude amplification and superposition of qubits, limitations of a classical Bayesian network can be overcome.

Github

Process

Bayesian networks are graphical models using directed acyclic graphs to represent variables and their dependencies. They infer likelihoods of dependence based on parent nodes, providing probabilities for outcomes given past events.

A quantum computing implementation can mitiage issues in classical bayesian networks, which can require many nodes, scale in computational complexity, and have poor performance on higher dimensional data.

The marginal/conditional probabilities of each node in the Bayesian network is matched to the probability ampltitudes with each state of a qubit. Rotation gates in the circuit realize the required probability amplitudes of the quantum states.

The circuits are then executed with Qiskit to emulate the function of a quantum computer. The generated probability becomes more accurate and precise with a higher number of executions. A histogram can be constructed to demonstrate the probabilities generated by the circuit.
